Local Wildlife - Cougar
image:image.image:caption: This powerful predator roams the Americas, where it is also known as a panther, puma, mountain lion, and catamount. This big cat of many names is also found in many habitats, from Florida swamps to Canadian forests.

image:image.image:title: Local Wildlife
image:image.image:caption: SIZE RELATIVE TO A 6-FT MAN:

image:image.image:title: Local Wildlife - Snakes
image:image.image:caption: Utah is home to many different species and subspecies of snakes, several of which are venomous.

image:image.image:title: Local Wildlife - Moose
image:image.image:caption: Moose are the largest of all the deer species. Males are immediately recognizable by their huge antlers, which can spread 6 feet from end to end. Moose have long faces and muzzles that dangle over their chins. A flap of skin known as a bell sways beneath each moose's throat.

image:image.image:title: Local Wildlife
image:image.image:caption: SIZE RELATIVE TO A 6-FT MAN:

image:image.image:title: Local Wildlife - Deer
image:image.image:caption: Mule deer are very common throughout the western United States. They are named for their oversized ears that resemble a mule's ears. Compared to its cousin, the white-tailed deer, mule deer are larger in size, and have a black-tipped white tail and white patch on the rump. They can be three feet tall at the shoulder and weigh anywhere between 100 and 300 pounds. They have excellent hearing and eyesight that warns them of approaching dangers.

image:image.image:title: Recreation
image:image.image:caption: Mantua has two campgrounds, one run by Mantua Waterfront RV, and the other is run by Box Elder County. Both are wonderful places to camp old school or pull in an RV. Click the links on the side for more information on making reservations and pricing.

image:image.image:title: Mantua Trails - FireHouse Trail Work
image:image.image:caption: Over the course of 3 months, 40 different people, 10 evenings for 2 hours each week, an average of 6 people to total an approximate 120 hours. 1 mile of trail, half done by hand, half done by a tractor.
